displaytitle: Marcus Valerius Corvus, from the series The Roman Heroes
creditline: Bequest of Duane E. Wilder, Class of 1951

makers.displaydate: 1558–1617; born Mülbracht, Netherlands; died Haarlem, Netherlands
makers.displaymaker: Hendrick Goltzius, 1558–1617; born Mülbracht, Netherlands; died Haarlem, Netherlands

texts.textentryhtml: As in the seven other engravings of muscular men in Goltzius’s The Roman Heroes series, the background details of this composition reflect the artist’s reading of the Roman historian Livy, who related that Marcus Valerius, a military commander and consul during the Roman Republic, was assisted by a raven during his combat with a Gallic warrior—prompting the nickname “Corvus” (the Latin for “raven”). Typical of the series, the figure strikes an exaggerated pose, with his right arm twisted behind his back, and makes an elaborate gesture with his hand—an approach to the human figure we see elsewhere in the Wilder collection.
texts.remarks: The Eclectic Eye: A Tribute to Duane Wilder

displaymaker: Hendrick Goltzius, 1558–1617; born Mülbracht, Netherlands; died Haarlem, Netherlands
